item.title: Measures of network position and structure
item.description: Many networks that we find interesting are large and structurally complex. This makes them difficult to visually understand. And although coming up with ways to visualize such networks is a kind of fun, most of the time we need practical ways to describe the position and structure of complex networks without dealing with the tangled hairball. This post covers some a variety of ways to measure network position and structure.

item.title: Introduction to Networks in R
item.description: Data Structures The Square Matrix The Edgelist But Why? Bernouli Graph Simulation Network objects in igraph Matrix \(\rightarrow\) network Edgelist \(\rightarrow\) network Visualize igraph objects Network objects in statnet Visualize network objects References In this meeting, we cover the basics of working with networks in R. By the end of the workshop, you will be acquainted with three packages – igraph, statnet, and tidygraph – and you will be able to create a network from scratch, turn it into a network object, create vertex and edge attributes, and genereate a basic visualization.
